awd_titl_txt: Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
Award DMS 1440415, Principal Investigator Russell E. Caflisch


The mission of the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) is to foster the interaction of mathematics with a broad range of science and technology, to build new interdisciplinary research communities, to promote mathematical innovation, and to engage and transform the world through mathematics.  Mathematics is an essential ingredient in much of current technology, including internet search engines, medical imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography, voice recognition systems, DNA sequencing methods, and many others. Future developments -- such as smart electrical grids, personalized medicine, and new forms of social networking -- will require further mathematical innovation.  IPAM's overall goal is to foster the interaction of mathematicians with doctors, engineers, physical scientists, social scientists, and humanists to enable such future technological and social progress.
 
IPAM fulfills its mission through workshops and long programs that connect mathematics and other disciplines or multiple areas of mathematics. These activities bring in thousands of visitors annually from academia, government, and industry. IPAM also has programs that encourage the inclusion of women and members of minorities underrepresented in the mathematics community, that serve specific  needs of government agencies, and that inform the public about the excitement of modern mathematics and the important contributions that have come to society through mathematics.
 
Through these activities, IPAM serves the national interest. IPAM promotes the progress of science by stimulating the mathematical developments that are needed for this progress; advances the national health, prosperity, and welfare through programs that address challenges such as disease modeling, systemic financial risk assessment, and traffic control; and helps to secure the national defense through programs that address defense requirements such as advanced radar, computer-aided decision making, and new communication modalities.

por.por_cntn:
The award supported the activities of the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) for the period 2015-2022. The award supported the Institute?s mission of creating diverse and inclusive mathematical communities, bringing to bear mathematical tools on the problems of today.

During the period 2015-2022, IPAM ran a total of 14 long programs, and over 120 workshops, including reunions for our long programs; these were attended by over 8,000 mathematicians, statisticians, and other scientists for a total of over 17,000 person-visits.  The long programs were:

  • New Directions in Mathematical Approaches for Traffic Flow Management
  • Culture Analytics
  • Understanding Many-Particle Systems with Machine Learning
  • Computational Issues in Oil Field Applications
  • Complex High-Dimensional Energy Landscapes
  • Quantitative Linear Algebra
  • Science at Extreme Scales: Where Big Data Meets Large-Scale Computing
  • Geometry and Learning from Data in 3D and Beyond
  • Machine Learning for Physics and the Physics of Learning
  • High Dimensional Hamilton-Jacobi PDEs
  • Mathematical Challenges and Opportunities for Autonomous Vehicles
  • Tensor Methods and Emerging Applications to the Physical and Data Sciences
  • Mathematical and Computational Challenges in the Era of Gravitational Wave Astronomy
  • Advancing Quantum Mechanics with Mathematics and Statistics

Over 1,000 scientific papers by long program participants have resulted from IPAM activities, with some 300 new collaborations formed.  IPAM programs have promoted, and in certain cases initiated, the use of novel mathematical techniques in a variety of fields ranging from Social Sciences to Materials Science, Plasma Physics, Quantum Mechanics, to Autonomous Vehicles.  At the same time, new mathematical insights were gained, some driven by applications.

Long program participants produced White Papers summarizing new research directions. These are available on the IPAM web site, http://ipam.ucla.edu.  

A full list of our past workshops and other events is also available. 

Approximately half of IPAM long program participants are junior researchers, many of them graduate students and recent PhDs.  The program served to broaden their research networks and make it easy to include techniques from other fields of research in their work. 

Many IPAM visitors spoke of the significant impact of their research stays on their work, enabling new collaborations and promoting cross-fertilization between fields. A significant number of participants, including mathematicians and statisticians, reported that cross-disciplinary connections and collaborations created during IPAM programs were helpful in obtaining further research funding from sources outside DMS, or even NSF.

IPAM also held 5 graduate summer schools during the award period. Aimed at recent PhDs or advanced graduate students, these summer schools brought in leading scientists to give short courses and research talks to junior participants. These schools served as excellent introductions to a variety of subjects, from electronic structure of materials, to mean field games, to quantum computing, quantum and post-quantum cryptography, to issues of algorithmic fairness. 

The award also provided funding for IPAM's Research in Industrial Projects for Students (RIPS).  Over 250 students participated in that program in the last 7 years, working on cutting-edge mathematics related projects proposed by RIPS industry sponsors.  Many of the student teams presented results of their research work at national conferences. A significant portion of the teams published their results in scientific journals or conference proceedings.

Participation in the RIPS program has been an eye-opening experience for many young mathematicians, showcasing the multitude of career paths -- in and out of academia -- available to mathematics students.

During the award period, IPAM has played a significant role in addressing issues of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in mathematical sciences. This included encouraging participation by women and underrepresented minorities in all of our programs, as well as special programs aimed at increasing such representation. 

Additional time was needed to expend funds due to the pandemic-related postponement of in-person operations at IPAM.
